ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the history of fugues and various ways of thinking about them and analyzing them. I now have learned to see all things as in some way or another connected to one another.
This is a very specialized course on the context, constructions, and outcomes of fugue. One gains a general and specific academic and creative knowledge on the genre.

Analysis of fugues and some of the history of the genre and its perception. We created continuity charts of fugues using Google Sheets (an interesting way to analyze the macro scale of fugues). I especially liked the midterm presentations analyzing Bachs Art of Fugue because now I can understand the important compositional aspects of each fugue within it and what a masterpiece it is as a whole.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: A big strength about this course was that everyone was at a similar level, enough to note waste time in class teaching some catch up material. As a result, discussions were enriching and productive. One weakness was that the course was not extremely structured. At times it felt like we were just reading things and discussing them without them being a continuation on what we had discussed previously. Additionally, sometimes we wouldnt have enough time to sufficiently discuss the material we read.

Dr. Harrison's readings were fun to explore, while some of the rest were dense. I loved listening to the variety of types of fugues, and learning about how we might analyze and qualify fugues in general.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to another student who has the prerequisite knowledge of classical music, specifically baroque. Unfortunately, this is the last time it was offered.
Yes, because i think there is room for many different sorts of musicians in this course!
If they really like to get really nerdy about fugues, yes!
